vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/fd5cb368-4b51-44f6-970c-908acad4bf55">WAGES</keyword>         <topcClas>General - Employment and labour</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social and occupational mobility - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>This study developed a continuously-scaled indicator of social position (the 'Essex Score'), which was estimated as individuals' potential wages in the labour market.  The Essex Score was designed as a tool to investigate patterns of differentiation in life chances.  It was constructed based on individuals' educational qualifications, recent experience in employment and non-employment, and occupational attainment, using data from the first 13 waves of the <a href="http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/findingData/bhpsTitles.asp" title="British Household Panel Survey"><i>British Household Panel Survey</i></a> (BHPS) (held at the UK Data Archive (UKDA) under GN 33196), and also from the associated <i>British Household Panel Survey Combined Work-Life History Data, 1990-2003</i> study (held under SN 3954).<br> <br> The Essex Score represents those embodied economic resources salient to individuals' participation in the labour market, equivalent to 'human capital' in economic literature, and sometimes indicated by social class categories in sociological research.  It has advantages over other social class measures: being based on educational levels and on degrees of present and past attachment to the labour market, as well as on present or previous occupational membership, it covers the entire adult population irrespective of their employment status and employment history.  Its continuous-level measurement also allows aggregation of scores from an individual to a household level, as well as the sensitive investigation of the determinants and consequences of changes in social position during the life course.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The dataset includes a cross-wave case identifier from the BHPS, wage estimate data, Mean Occupation Wage (MOW) score and Essex Score data.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="1991-01-01T00:00:00Z">1991</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2004-01-01T00:00:00Z">2004</collDate>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Respondents to the BHPS Waves 1-13, between 1991 and 2004</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Data are taken from the longitudinal BHPS series</timeMeth>         <sampProc>See documentation for details</sampProc>         <deviat>29,100 cases</deviat>         <collMode>Compilation or synthesis of existing material</collMode>         <collMode>the original BHPS interviews were conducted face-to-face</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used for main BHPS. See BHPS documentation for details</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Available to all registered users for any use</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required.
